Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2008 07:42AM gsg wrote: There's no general rule for this.  Chemo is not a "one size fits all" kind of thing.  What worked for me, may not work for you and vice versa.  Fortunately, there are lots of drugs in the arsenal to try until they find the one(s) that will work for you.  LuAnn, don't you have a list somewhere of treatments?  My chemobrain has me so mentally challenged, I can't be sure of that, but I thought you did.
Posts.Title: How soon after chemo treatments before I see a lump change? lovinmomma LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 09:45AM - edited Mar 31, 2008 09:46AM by gsg Another thing to consider is just because the breast cancer is not in the lymph nodes does not mean a few stray cells are not circulating through the body. Breast cancer also spreads through the lymph system and blood stream.  I had clear lymph nodes, but biopsy report said "suspicious for lymphatic invasion."  This is different than having it in the nodes.  The purpose of chemo is to knock out the stray cells that may not be picked up in tests...it's systemic.  It's good that you are arming yourselves with as much info as possible before your wife makes her treatment decisions.   Best wishes to you both- Patrice (GSG)
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 05:26AM gsg wrote: I'm er/pr+ but Her2-...stage 2, grade 2, no nodes, clear margins...while chemo wasn't easy, I wanted it, so down the road I would not be second-guessing decisions made should I have a recurrence.  You didn't say what grade her tumor is.  That's another consideration...how aggressive is the tumor?  For me, I needed to know my docs had thrown the book at it the first time around.  I was able to have a lumpectomy and felt comfortable with that decision, once I found out mastectomy did not reduce my odds of a recurrence.  I had 4 rounds dose-dense A/C and 4 rounds dose-dense Taxol.  It's physically harder getting it dose dense, but there is a slight statistical difference in recurrence rates and so that's the way I went. I had my ovaries removed so I could take Arimidex for 5 years, but I was 50 at the time.  If I were younger, I would have taken the Tamoxifen.  In fact, I feel very fortunate to have something I can still take every day...mentally, it's comforting.  At the end of 5 years, if my bones are okay, I'm going to ask if I can stay on it.  After 16 months, I've had no side effects. I would also recommend reading about flax seed and breast cancer.  I'm starting now to ingest 3 TBS of freshly ground flax seed a day.  Studies show, it can reduce breast cancer tumors.  I figure it can't hurt. Bottom line, though, your wife must be comfortable and at peace with the decisions made, and in this journey, everybody's emotions and needs are different.   Good luck to you both.
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 05:33PM gsg wrote: Others will have to advise you regarding those chemo drugs.  Re tumor grade...do you have her biopsy/pathology report?  The tumor grade should be listed on there.  It will be a grade 1, grade 2 or grade 3, with grade 1 being the least aggressive, grade 2 intermediate, and grade 3 the most aggressive. As an aside, if your wife hasn't done this already (or been given one by her doctor's office), put together a 3-ring notebook and every time a test is done or a report is issued, get a copy of it and stick it in the book.  (They have to give it to you.)  Stick it in a satchel and have it with her everywhere she goes.  You have no idea how important this is and how much it will be used.  I still keep mine in the trunk of my car and take it in with me for every doctor's appt.  Cancer can be a full-time job for a while, and it's made a lot easier if you can keep the stuff organized. Here's a link to a thread that has a description and picture of the patient book I use.  It's still my bible and other specialists I go to (even noncancer related), are happy to have all the reports & history right at their fingertips.  http://community.breastcancer.org/topic/7/conversation/702723?page=1#comment_866871 take care- Patrice (GSG)
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2007 10:51PM gsg wrote: 1 month after ending chemo, i had my ovaries removed at the same time as they did my lumpectomy.  they tried, but were not able to do it laparscopically and so i had an abdominal incision.  healing time was the normal 6 weeks...and i was undergoing rads while healing. in 1997, i had a partial hysterectomy (everything but ovaries removed) done vaginally.  there was NO PAIN at all having it done that way and recovery was a snap.  good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2008 10:21AM - edited Apr 8, 2008 10:22AM by gsg Try drinking flattened ginger ale.  To flatten it, pour it back and forth between two glasses until it stops fizzing and bubbling.  Drink that and also eat some saltine crackers.  I hope this gives you some relief.  Peppermint tea might help as well.  Mint is supposed to calm the stomach, I think.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 01:04PM - edited Mar 23, 2008 01:08PM by gsg I'm er/pr+.  i gained between 30 & 40 pounds during chemo....it would fluctuate wildly from day to day.  Started chemo end of April and was at my top weight by June.   postchemo it took me several months to take off 20 of them..hard to lose on arimidex...lots of stress in my life, i'm an emotional eater, and i have now put them all back on.  it's been one of the worst side effects of cancer for me, as it has done a number on me mentally. It's the steroids that kick the appetite into overdrive...so try to surround yourself with only healthy foods and, if you can do it, exercise as much as possible.  i know there are lots of women who do not gain while on chemo, so don't get too discouraged.

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2007 07:19PM gsg wrote: I agree it's at epidemic stages.  When I was in my 20s and my parents were the age I am now...50s....we hardly knew anyone their age or my age with cancer.  Flash forward to today, and I can't count how many people i know who have cancer...young and old...some who are close to me and many acquaintances.  something is wrong.  i don't believe it's just better diagnostic tools.  it was a rarity for people to die, period, in their 20s, 30s, 40s and 50s...not so any more.  also, seeing bald-headed women and children is becoming commonplace. i'm scared for the future generations.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2008 03:17PM - edited Apr 12, 2008 03:19PM by gsg Deb: I was googling to see if I could find any answers for you and stumbled upon this.  I'm not sure if it truly means they shouldn't be able to apply lifetime maximums, or if it applies only to people who have purchased insurance on their own, but it's interesting and might be worth a call to find out about it. http://yourtotalhealth.ivillage.com/plan-limits-lifetime-benefit.html  "There is a small controversy nationwide about maximum benefits in light of federal law. The "Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996" (HIPAA) requires guaranteed renewability for all health plans, including individual insurance. The law says that "a health insurance issuer that provides individual health insurance coverage to an individual shall renew or continue in force such coverage at the option of the individual." There are several exceptions. Again, according to the law, "A health insurance issuer may nonrenew or discontinue health insurance coverage of an individual in the individual market based only on one or more of the following: (1) Nonpayment of premiums; (2) Fraud; (3) Termination of plan; (4) Movement outside service area." As you see, this list does not include an exception for reaching a lifetime maximum benefit. If you have a question about the applicability of this law with respect to a lifetime maximum benefit on your plan, consult the insurance company or call your state's insurance department. "

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 04:52AM - edited Apr 10, 2008 04:52AM by gsg Pam:  You and I are exactly the same age...I just turned 52 at the end of February.  Nobody in my family has ever had osteoporosis that I know of, so it must be genetics.  Flax messes with estrogen, but some recent studies have shown that it's still beneficial for estrogen + women and has been shown to reduce breast cancer tumors.  To get breast cancer benefits from it, the flax must be ground and used within a couple hours of the grinding, according to what I've read. So sorry you are having breast pain.  I don't have anything to offer in the way of help for it.  So glad you are nearing the end, though!
Posts.Title: itchy red bumps-like hives Pam40 Pam40

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 09:38AM - edited Apr 11, 2008 09:39AM by gsg Jim, I had IDC, Stage, II, hormone pos, herceptin neg, FIVE tumors, (4 found as a result of the MRI) the largest being almost 3 cms, and I was able to have a lumpectomy because they were all in the same area and because I did my chemo upfront to shrink them.   This could possibly be an option for your wife, depending on her breast size and how much tissue has to come out.  It's worth asking about.   Mastectomy and lumpectomy w/chemo & rads have the same recurrence rates. What was nice about doing chemo first was I was able to feel the tumors shrinking.  By the time they did surgery, there were no live cancer cells left.  As others have said, chemo is different for everybody...some girls breeze through...others it's rougher, but definitely doable.  I never had one moment of nausea...the meds for side effects today are remarkable. Rads also were no problem for me.  I'm now on a drug similar to Tamox, but given to postmenopausal women, Arimidex, and have had no side effects from that either. Breast cancer does change your life forever, but it turned out the treatment part was not at all as bad as I was expecting. Good luck to you both! Patrice (GSG)

Posts.Title: Silent Dread SLH snowyday

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 02:27AM gsg wrote: I had that after my 2nd or 3rd rad tx and was able to get rid of them by switching from biafine cream to calendula ointment (purchased over the counter at a vitamin store).  I kept pure aloe vera in the refrigerator and this was very soothing.  Also used baby powder with cornstarch.  The other thing I did was shower three times a day.  Also, I went swimming each day following rads and made sure I put the calendula on liberally before swimming..then I would shower and reapply.  I'd shower before bed and sometimes would put nothing on my skin to sleep to allow it to breathe, other times I'd just apply the aloe and sometimes just the baby powder. I never experienced radiation fatigue and I credit that to swimming laps for 1 hour each day.  I think the coolness of the water also helped. Good luck to you...you're almost there!
Posts.Title: itchy red bumps-like hives Pam40 Pam40

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 03:50AM gsg wrote: the itchy red bumps went away within days of changing ointments and starting swimming.  my rad onc at first was hesitant about the chlorine, but i promised her i would take meticulous care of my skin...and i think the swimming, calendula and 3 showers a day is what kept my skin looking and feeling good.  i finished rads end of November 2006 and the only difference between my radiated side now and the nonradiated is i do have a little bit of orange peel effect on the breast skin and the radiated side is firmer and perkier.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 08:10PM gsg wrote: Tracy: Your request at the end of your post asking for hope brought to mind a poem that was given to me by my breast center when I was first diagnosed.  It was tucked into my "patient notebook." HOPE "Hope" is the thing with feathers-   That perches in the soul- And sings the song without the words-   And never stops -- at all --   And sweetest in the Gale is heard-   And sore must be the storm- That could abash the little Bird   That kept so many warm-   I've heard it in the chillest land-   And on the strangest Sea-    Yet, never, in extremity,   It asked a crumb of me.  Emily Dickinson Hang on and keep fighting.  Good luck to you tomorrow and in the days ahead and I pray that Taxol is the one that's going to do it for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2008 09:44AM - edited Mar 25, 2008 09:55AM by gsg I'm with you, LuAnn.  WHAT is going on?  And WHY is it hitting so many young women?  When I was a young woman, I knew only one woman who had breast cancer.  Now it seems just about every family I know has been touched by it.  I don't buy that the diagnostic tools are better and so we just know about it now.  When I was in elementary, middle, and high school, my classmates' parents were NOT dying from cancer.  I worked for large corporations in my 20s and 30s and my coworkers were not fighting breast cancer.  As I said, I knew of only one.  Fast forward to today and the girl who sits at the  desk next to me at work was diagnosed with breast cancer within a month of my diagnosis.  The woman who USED to sit at my desk had breast cancer.  One of my coworkers recently lost his mother to bc...the list goes on and on. My mother and I read through the angels list on the board yesterday....besides being completely heartbroken, we had a sense of incredulousness and outrage...but also helplessness.
Posts.Title: This is just so sad... waterlily gsg

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2008 07:10AM gsg wrote: I agree with what heidi said.  I knew from the beginning I was getting chemo because that's the only way lumpectomy would be an option for me....they had to shrink the largest tumor first.  It didn't matter that I had clear nodes.  Never got onco testing as a result...but that wouldn't have mattered for me.  I mentally needed to know that they had thrown everything they had at my cancer the first time out.  Got all my chemo dose dense as well...it's a little more difficult physically, but it's the most aggressive way to go at it and has a slight statistical advantage as far as recurrence rates...plus, you get it over with faster. At least now, if I have a recurrence, I will not be second guessing any decisions made 2 years ago.  For me, that was important.  But you will find with this disease, everybody's emotional (and physical) needs are different and it's important all decisions made in your wife's case are what makes her the most comfortable.  As you move further along this path, you will come to realize how "individual" this disease is...it's different for each person...the treatments, side effects, emotional impact.  That really surprised me.  It's what makes this board so helpful...while not everybody will experience a particular side effect or issue, someone will come along who has and can shed insight.
Posts.Title: My wife just was diagnosed with IDC jn06 Labgal

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 05:13AM gsg wrote: Pam, you just made MY day...so happy to help.  You are absolutely not alone with this reaction.  Lots of women have it.  Sometimes I'd like to shake the people who treat us....I've heard of other women being told "that's not caused by radiation."  Ridiculous! Here's a study on the calendula ointment published in the reputable Journal of Clinical Oncology.  It was comparing calendula with biafine and you can see how much better the calendula was. (I bought the ointment, not the cream.)  I think it was about $7 for a tube.  I hope you are able to get some relief.  Also, as I said, keep the pure aloe in the refrigerator.  It really does feel soothing and cool when you rub it on. jco.ascopubs.org/cgi/content/f...   Keep me posted on how the rest of your treatments go.  I'm going to be watching for you. Take care- Patrice (GSG)

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2007 05:54AM gsg wrote: A couple weeks ago, I heard a coworker say, in regard to someone else being diagnosed with cancer, "Well, any of us could get hit by a truck tomorrow."  Like it's the same kind of crapshoot. I told her the difference is, you're standing up on the curb and those of us who have the diagnosis are standing in the middle of the road staring at oncoming headlights.  Sure, the truck *could* jump the curb and take you out...but which one of us do you think has the best (or worst) odds?  I also asked her if she would care to switch places and take the middle of the road and i'll get up on the curb.
Posts.Title: Have u ever encountered anyones attitude without BC? Ter EnergizerBunny

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2008 04:46PM gsg wrote: Yay!  That is great news, Susan.  It's possible they didn't have a precise measurement to start off with, but I can tell you from personal experience my lump, which was very palpable, started shrinking after my first chemo and continued to shrink with each one.  By the time I had my last chemo, you could no longer feel it.  When they did my lumpectomy at the end of chemo, my surgeon said it was basically a "ghostectomy," and all cells removed were dead.  For me, I was happy to have my chemo upfront.   It gave me physical proof that it was doing its job and that's what I believe is happening in your case as well.  The chemo is kicking your cancer to the curb.

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2011 05:31PM gsg wrote: Stage 1 is very early stage and has an excellent prognosis.  Once you educate yourself on the stage of your mother's disease, you will probably relax a little.  The early part right after diagnosis is very scary. I think the grade level is more about the aggressiveness of the tumor...there are three grades; 1 being the least aggressive, 2 being moderately aggressive and 3 being the most aggressive, which may be playing into her doctor's decision to go with chemo.  Chemo, while not easy, was much easier than I thought it would be and it gave me peace of mind getting it, knowing it was killing all the cancer.  I never experienced any nausea, etc....just fatigue.   Good luck to your mother!

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2008 08:58AM - edited Mar 22, 2008 08:59AM by gsg Jackie: While I was going through chemo, for the longest time, I skipped pedicures because I was embarrassed by my swollen feet with missing toenails.  I would still go in for manicures.  One day the owner asked me why I stopped pedicures and I started to cry...and told her I didn't want anyone to see my feet.  She threw up her hands and said, "You don't have anything that we haven't seen before and we've seen much worse."  She made me get in the pedicure chair, turned on the back massager, and went to town on my feet.  My neuropathy was horrible and the massage felt sooooooooo good! I may have been bald, bloated and funky on the outside, but she made me feel like a girl on the inside and i walked out with a smile on my face looking at my 8 painted toenails. Here's a toast to your first postchemo pedicure!  Enjoy!

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 08:19AM gsg wrote: Pryclla:  Please invite your mother to join us.  This place calmed me down immediately!  I have found it's the best site on the internet for breast cancer patients..great tips on handling side effects and also to take care of our emotional needs...my experience anyway.  I, too, had IDC, with 5 tumors, the largest being almost 3 cms, the other 4 were all around it and tiny.  My breast surgeon at first told me she was sure it must be in my lymph nodes..but when they did the sentinel node biopsy, it was discovered they were clean.   So the docs don't know everything. I had chemo prior to lumpectomy and by the time they did my surgery,  ALL cancer cells were dead.  Chemo is not easy, but not as bad as I thought it would be and I found out I actually liked having no hair, which was a shock because I had pretty good hair and don't have the "face" to look good without any.  But it was great being able to shower and run.  I even stopped wearing my wigs.  Radiation truly was a breeze for me.  So treatment turned out not to be as daunting as I first feared. My cancer year was 2 years ago and there is now no evidence of disease.  This could be your mother's path as well. Once you and your mother start learning more about breast cancer and her specifics, you'll be able to relax and start taking control of her life again. Good luck to you both- Patrice (GSG)

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2008 09:03PM gsg wrote: i was told i could only use lotions that were approved by my radiation onc. keep the aloe in the refrigerator...very soothing. nonprescription calendula ointment worked better for me than biafine.  there's a study published in the journal of clinical oncology where calendula performed better than biafine.  i showed it to my rad onc and she approved it.  i went swimming every day immediately after radiation, would rub calendula on before and shower immediately after and rub some more and my skin remained flawless through radiation.  daily swimming also prevented me from getting radiation fatigue as well. good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 01:09PM - edited Apr 11, 2010 01:23PM by gsg Insurance reform may help you this year.  High risk pools should be set up in 90 days from the date of the new bill.  They will provide coverage for people with pre-existing conditions.  There's more to it than that and I can't get the copy and paste function to work on here.  So google insurance reform and high risk pools and read about it.  Hope this helps. here's a link to one article:  www.slate.com/id2248560/ edited to provide link to one article.   if that link doesn't work for you google slate high risk pools and a frequently asked questions from this website will be the second google offering.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 10:13AM - edited Mar 23, 2008 10:21AM by gsg during chemo, i had gone to a podiatrist re my toenails, and he had recommended ANODYNE therapy to treat the neuropathy in my feet.  At the time, I blew it off because I didn't need to add one more doctor's appointment to my schedule and my neuropathy wasn't debilitating. i wonder if it would help you.  might be worth looking into.  if you google anodyne, you'll see it's used mostly for diabetics, but here's one article where they do mention neuropathy due to chemo.  also, i *think* it's covered by insurance.  edit:  It does say for active cancers, check with your doctor to see if it's safe.  It might be worth at least asking about it. http://www.wiregrasstherapy.com/new_page_6.htm

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2008 07:04AM - edited Oct 9, 2008 07:04AM by gsg You sound like such a nice guy! I'm not sure how elevated the risk, but I was told during chemo that there's germs on flowers, so you must be careful not to handle them when blood counts are low. I was also told to warn people not to hug me, which is a natural response when people see you, especially if they know you are sick.  I kept hand sanitizers handy and used them a lot. Good luck to your girlfriend...she's lucky to have such a supportive boyfriend.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2008 03:26PM - edited Apr 12, 2008 03:41PM by gsg Another thing is it never hurts to contact your representatives.  Send letters to Senators Stevens & Murkowski..tell them  about your plight.  You'd be surprised how much attention they do pay to letters sent in from constituents.  Senators are constantly reading letters on the floor (or in committee hearings) citing examples of stuff that is happening to everyday people in their states.   Sometimes they don't read them out loud, but they submit them for the record and the letter will be printed  in the Congressional Record for posterity.  (I work for the Senate and listen to their statements all day long) Even though they are Republicans and probably not in support of a national health care system, they will still listen to what you have to say and may be willing to push for legislation to lift lifetime caps.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2010 07:00AM gsg wrote: I haven't heard the sloshing, but I do have the fluid...it's called a seroma.  My surgery was in Sept '06, the seroma suddenly appeared the following January...it was drained once and immediately refilled and it's still there 3 1/2 years later.  Since it doesn't hurt, I'm not going to have it drained again.  Have no idea why the fluid isn't reabsorbing, but it kind of fills the dent in from the lumpectomy so I'm okay with it being there.
Posts.Title: Sloshing Sound after Lumpectomy JudyAnnW Cassia101

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2010 04:41AM gsg wrote: Hey, Cheryl...During chemo, senekot and all the OTC's didn't work for me...none of the home remedies, like prunes, etc, did either..uncomfortable and frustrating...FINALLY, an elderly woman from "the old country" told me to add 1 to 2 tablespoons of molasses to a glass of warm water and drink before going to bed.  Worked like a charm for me.  Hope this helps and that you find some relief soon.
